headline: Ask HN: Programming ideas that redefine the way you look at programming
description:
What are the ideas in programming that once you saw you could never go back looking into other programs the same way. For e.g, one a recent HN thread about units[0] one user shared a F# snippet like this

    unit type Meters = m
    unit type Seconds = s
    val speed = 5.4 m/s
I'm unfamiliar with F# but having units right next to value is something i'll be remembering everyday from now on[1]

Some other ideas that changed the way i look at programs.

* Lisp Macros * First class functions. Passing functions as a value is something that i do everyday. * Garbage collection. Not having to worry about memory allocation is such a relief.

The last 2 points are surprisingly a common pattern now, but for someone coming from C[2] and shell scripting its a whole different world here.

======

[0]: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=30749134 [1]: In school we were made to write units next to values, Now that ive seen it, i ask myself why don't more languages support this. [2]: i'm aware of function pointers in C but its something that i rarely used(iirc qsort expected it).
